description: From Latin pontificatus, from pontifex (“high priest”), from pons (“bridge”) + facere (“make”).

entries.meaning: The status or term of office of a pontiff or pontifex.

description: From the past participle stem of mediaeval Latin pontificare (“pontificate”), from Latin pontifex (“high priest”), from pons (“bridge”) + facere (“make”).

verbs.description: pontificate (third-person singular simple present pontificates, present participle pontificating, simple past and past participle pontificated)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To preside as a bishop, especially at mass.
(intransitive) To act like a pontiff; to express one's position or opinions dogmatically and pompously as if they were absolutely correct.
(intransitive) To speak in a patronizing, supercilious or pompous manner, especially at length.
